In December, I met with senior White House officials who, along with @SecMayorkas, Deputy Secretary John Tien & State Department staff, helped arrange for thorough vetting of the Afghans, & processed them for Temporary Protected Status here.  12/14

When we returned to DC, Senator Ernst & I got dozens of members of the House and Senate, both Democrat & Republican, to sign a letter lobbying the White House to vet & let these Afghans - who risked so much for us - start a life in the U.S. 11/14

They asked us, quite simply, not to forget them. What I told them was this: I could not forget them, because I saw in each of them the faces of my grandparents & great-grandparents who, many years ago, left their home countries for a safer & more prosperous life in the U.S. 10/14

In November, I led a bipartisan codel to Albania to meet with many in this group. My trip coincided with a similar trip by @SenJoniErnst & we traveled together to visit the Afghans. It‚Äôs no exaggeration to say that this was one of the most moving experiences of my career. 9/14 http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FOF9g_8XEAEWBN_.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FOF9g_7X0Ak6d_z.jpg

A wonderful NGO, @SpiritAmerica Worldwide, covered their expenses & cared for them as a group. I am deeply indebted to them & the Government of Albania for welcoming these Afghans in, on extremely short notice, & serving as refuge in their time of need.  8/14

Through a few amazing coincidences and connections, the Afghans were welcomed to Albania, where the government generously agreed to host them. The Foreign Minister @xhacka_olta  met them on the tarmac, along with @USAmbAlbania Yuri Kim, who did so much to make it happen. 7/14

Over almost 2 weeks, we worked around the clock with folks across the globe to get these Afghans into a convoy of rented busses, through 28 hours trying to get past dangerous Taliban checkpoints, into the airport, onto charter flights & to safety out of Afghanistan. 6/14

In addition to the 70 people in this group who were studying & working through MSU, we learned of another 30+ who were former deputy ministers & staff of the former Afghan government. All had worked for or with the U.S. & all were in danger because of their connection to us. 5/14

It all started when my team and I became aware of a group of Afghan nationals affiliated with Michigan State University who were in danger as the Taliban moved in on Kabul last summer.  4/14 https://www.washingtonpost.com/national-security/interactive/2021/kabul-airlift-afghans-escape/
Today, I‚Äôm thrilled to share that after 7 months of waiting to be screened and vetted abroad, they are arriving next week in the United States. 3/14

An incredibly rag-tag effort of US veterans, non-profit leaders, former national security professionals and a whole bunch of brave people on the ground in Kabul got them out to the airport, and out of the country. 2/14

I want to pass along a great story, and the completion of a 7-month journey many of us have been on: Last August, as Kabul fell, my team and I helped evacuate more than 114 Afghans to safety, many of whom were scientists affiliated with @MichiganStateU. 1/14

RT @JemarTisby I was grateful to be part of a group of experts presenting to members of Congress about the threat of white Christian nationalism. Special thanks to @BJC @FFRF, @RepRaskin and @RepHuffman. Here are some takeways from the meeting...

Make no mistake ‚Äî the CROWN Act is a necessary step toward absolving our country‚Äôs original sin of racism.

And I challenge anyone to tell me that this isn't a cause worth fighting for. (11/11)

As Members of Congress, we must pass legislation that promotes diversity over discrimination and inclusivity over intolerance. For if we do so, we can create a fairer, more just world for young Black women and girls like my granddaughter to grow up in. (10/11)

With the CROWN Act, we can eliminate one such struggle. 

Although 188 of them blocked passage of my bill last month, I truly hope my Republican colleagues will take the opportunity today to stand against racial discrimination. (9/11)

To write off hair discrimination as an unimportant issue is to suggest that Congress need not address the still-prevalent issue of systemic racism. This represents a blatant disregard for the struggles of Black people ‚Äî especially Black women and girls ‚Äî in our country. (8/11)

However, the Court encouraged Congress to bring clarity to this issue. With the CROWN Act, we‚Äôre doing just that.

Specifically, we are rightfully stating that discrimination against Black hair is discriminating against Black people, and that is unacceptable. (7/11)

In EEOC v. Catastrophe Management Solutions, in which a Black prospective employee had her offer rescinded for refusing to alter her natural hair, the SCOTUS ruled that the policy was legal because it was supposedly race-neutral ‚Äî despite discriminating against Black hair. (6/11)

Black people face discrimination in nearly all aspects of life ‚Äî at the office, in the classroom and elsewhere ‚Äî simply because of the way their hair naturally grows out of their head. 

In fact, hair discrimination has quite literally cost Black people their jobs. (5/11)

Our nation‚Äôs systemic problems demand systemic solutions.

The GOP will not acknowledge that one such problem is systemic racism. The CROWN Act is a necessary step toward ending that. (2/11)
